name: Classical Mechanics
description: This course is an introduction to the principles of classical mechanics. Students will learn about classical mechanics, including kinematics, dynamics, classical potential energy, linear momentum, rotational motion, vector calculus, Lagrangian mechanics, Hamiltonian mechanics, and conservation principles.

name: Mathematical Methods
description: This course provides an introduction to the mathematical techniques required for advanced physics courses, including linear algebra, complex analysis, Fourier series, vector calculus, and partial differential equations.

name: Electricity and Magnetism
description: This course will introduce students to the principles of electricity and magnetism, including electrostatics, magnetostatics, electromagnetic waves, and optics.

name: Mathematical Physics
description: This course will introduce students to mathematical techniques used in advanced physics courses, including Fourier analysis, group theory, and special functions.

name: Modern Physics
description: This course is an introduction to modern physics, including quantum mechanics and relativity.

name: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: This course is an introduction to the principles of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, including entropy, temperature, heat, work, and applications in astrophysics.

name: Electrodynamics
description: This course will introduce students to the principles of electrodynamics, including Maxwell's equations and electromagnetic waves.

name: Astrophysics
description: This course is an introduction to astrophysics, including stellar astrophysics, galaxies, and cosmology.

name: Gravitational Physics
description: This course is an introduction to the principles of Einstein's theory of general relativity, including black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmology.

name: Nuclear and Particle Physics
description: This course is an introduction to the principles of nuclear and particle physics, including the Standard Model and applications in astrophysics.

name: Introductory Physics
description: This course introduces students to basic concepts in physics, such as mechanics, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, waves and optics, and modern physics.

name: Introductory Astronomy
description: This course introduces students to the principles of astronomy, such as celestial mechanics, observations and instrumentation, stellar and galactic astronomy, and cosmology.

name: Classical Mechanics
description: This course introduces students to classical mechanics, including kinematics, forces, energy, momentum, and rotational motion.

name: Electromagnetism
description: This course introduces students to electromagnetism, including electric and magnetic fields, Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance, circuits, and Maxwell's equations.

name: Thermal Physics
description: This course introduces students to thermal physics, including temperature, heat, entropy, kinetic theory, and thermodynamics.

name: Quantum Mechanics
description: This course introduces students to quantum mechanics, including wave-particle duality, uncertainty principle, Schr√∂dinger equation, hydrogen atom, and quantum states of atoms and molecules.

name: Optics
description: This course introduces students to optics, including geometrical and wave optics, interference, diffraction, polarization, and lasers.

name: Astrophysics I
description: This course introduces students to astrophysics, including stellar structure, evolution, and nucleosynthesis, and observational techniques, such as spectroscopy and photometry.

name: Astrophysics II
description: This course covers topics in astrophysics, such as black holes, neutron stars, white dwarfs, gravitational waves, high-energy astrophysics, and cosmology.
